item.title: Ukraine’s Interim Leader Asks for U.N. Peacekeepers
item.description: The request from Ukraine’s acting president reflected the limited options of the still-wobbly government in Kiev in a showdown with Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian demonstrators built a barricade in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk on Monday.

item.title: U.N. Rights Chief Condemns ‘Rampant’ Torture in Syria
item.description: The report condemns “routine” use of torture by the government, but also torture by some opposition groups, and cites allegations of abuse of children.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Nigeria Bus Station Blast Kills Scores
item.description: At least 71 people were killed when an explosion ripped through a crowded bus station. Officials blamed Boko Haram, the homegrown Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: By MUSIKILU MOJEED and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Scores Killed as Blast Hits Bus Depot Near Nigerian Capital
item.description: A bomb at a crowded bus station on the outskirts of Abuja killed at least 71 people during rush hour on Monday morning, raising concerns about the spread of an Islamist insurgency.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Pistorius Weeps as He Resumes Testimony
item.description: The prosecutor has challenged the track star Oscar Pistorius’s version of the killing of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, last year.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arrived at the high court in Pretoria, South Africa, on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Lessons for the Largest Democracy From a Much Smaller One
item.description: The author says a message of peace from Oscar Arias, the former president of Costa Rica, offered some ideas that resonate during India’s election season.
item.dc:creator: By DILIP D'SOUZA
item.media:description: Oscar Arias, former president of Costa Rica, addressing a news conference in San Jos, Costa Rica in 2009.

item.title: Special Report: Well Appointed: A Taste of Asia in the Heart of Europe
item.description: Shangri-La, synonymous with luxury but relatively unknown outside Asia, continues its westward push at a sky-high location in London.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BELCHER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: City Says Water Meets Safety Standards, But Residents Remain Cautious
item.description: Officials in the northwestern Chinese city of Lanzhou have declared that a faulty pipeline was repaired and that the water supply now meets safety standards.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Residents of Lanzhou, Gansu Province, lined up to buy bottled water after an oil pipe leak caused excessive levels of benzene in the city's water supply.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Arrest Order for Fugitive Hong Kong Tycoon Reaffirmed
item.description: A Hong Kong judge has upheld the arrest warrant for the newspaper tycoon Ma Sik-chun, who fled to Taiwan 36 years ago after being charged with drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH

item.title: After Delays, Syria Completes Another Shipment of Chemical Arms
item.description: The chemical weapons watchdog said that Syria had sent nearly two-thirds of its arsenal for destruction, but that it was uncertain if it would meet its deadline.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Searchers to Deploy Submersible in Hunt for Missing Jet
item.description: Officials said that after six days with no new possible black-box signals, it was time to take the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 underwater.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE, CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 14
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Monday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A rickshaw puller waiting for passengers in Kolkata, capital of the Indian state of West Bengal.

item.title: Prime Minister of Libya Says He Will Resign
item.description: Abdullah al-Thinni, the second to step down from the post in two months, said he would stay on as leader of the cabinet until a replacement could be found.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ron Pundak, a Key Israeli in Oslo Accords, Dies at 59
item.description: Mr. Pundak, an academic enlisted to take part in the secret negotiations with Palestinian officials that led to the historic agreement, remained an ardent advocate for peace.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Ron Pundak at a conference at Tel Aviv University in January. “Ron was a hero of peace,” the Israeli justice minister said.

item.title: American’s Wish for Iranian Burial Riles Hard-Liners
item.description: Politics intrudes after the death of Richard Nelson Frye, 94, a noted Harvard scholar who loved a land and its culture.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: In New Officers’ Careers, Peace Is No Dividend
item.description: West Point graduates, faced with the prospect of leading troops who are battle-tested when they themselves are not, are reconsidering their career paths in a military no longer fighting two wars.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and THOM SHANKER

item.title: Bus Crashes and Burns in Mexico, Killing at Least 36
item.description: The victims were businesspeople who were traveling from Villahermosa in Tabasco State to Mexico City when the bus slammed into a broken-down truck.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Buys Glencore Copper Mine Stake
item.description: The $5.85 billion cash deal is one of the biggest mining acquisitions in recent years for China, the world’s top copper consumer.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Discontent Swells as President of Algeria Seeks a Fourth Term
item.description: Despite evidence of frail health, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, 77, insisted on running again, a move that has united both secular and Islamic parties in their call to boycott the election.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By AMIR JALAL ZERDOUMI and CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Supporters of Algeria’s President Abdelaziz Bouteflika rallied on Sunday. Questions lingered about the president’s health, and opposition parties united in a call to boycott the election.

item.title: Rjukan Journal: Beaming Good Cheer to a Norwegian Town’s Dark Days
item.description: Three giant mirrors on a mountain reflect sunlight onto a small Norwegian town that gets very little of it in the winter. But not everyone is happy with the project.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Kyrre Lien for The New York Times
item.media:description: In winter, the town square of Rjukan, Norway, is illuminated by sunlight reflected from three computer-controlled mirrors on a mountain overlooking the town.

item.title: Sanctions Are Eased; Iran Sees Little Relief
item.description: Analysts say foreign business interest in Iran has remained extremely limited amid a temporary deal allowing increased economic ties.
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Series of Bombings Kills More Than 20 Across Iraq
item.description: All of the attacks came less than a week after the 11th anniversary of the toppling of a statue of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, an event that many Iraqis regard as the fall of the capital.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Ambiguities of Japan's Nuclear Policy
item.description: Japan has pioneered a type of nuclear deterrence that relies not on any overt threat, but on the mere suggestion of a latent possibility.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By NORIHIRO KATO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Two Nations, Related by Fear
item.description: The U.K. and the U.S. share a troubling role in stripping British citizens of their rights.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CLIVE STAFFORD SMITH

item.title: Partial Afghan Results Portend a Runoff as Fraud Is Cited
item.description: Official results of 10 percent of votes cast in 26 of Afghanistan’s 34 provinces showed that two candidates were leading. A runoff election appeared more certain.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
